{{Infobox company | | name = CWC Group Limited | | logo = [[Image:CWC Group Logo.png|100px]] | | type = [[Limited company]] | | foundation = 1997 | | location = [[United Kingdom|UK]] | | services = Conferences, Exhibitions, Training courses | homepage = [http://www.thecwcgroup.com www.thecwcgroup.com] }}
'''CWC Group Limited''' is an energy and infrastructure conference, exhibition and training company that was established in 1997 by Tim Clark, Alirio Parra and Lisa Shelton.
CWC Group Limited provides international business executives with Government summits, International industry conferences, Exhibitions, Private retreats, Roadshows, Bespoke consultancy, Recruitment Fairs, Recruitment Process Outsourcing, Public training courses and In-house training courses.<ref name="corporate">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecwcgroup.com/corporate|title=CWC Group's "About Us"|accessdate=2011-02-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209033014/http://www.thecwcgroup.com/corporate/#|archive-date=2011-02-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Bw">{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=112321317|title=Bloomberg Business Week - CWC Group Limited Company Information|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
In 2007 and 2011, CWC Group Limited won the [[Queen's Awards for Enterprise|Queen's Award For Enterprise]] – International Trade<ref name="queen">{{cite web |url=http://www.mvpicton.co.uk/cache/The%20Queen%27s%20Award%20for%20Enterprise%20Crest%20Nicholson%20Plc.htm|title=The Queen's Award For Enterprise Website|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="queen2">{{cite web|url=https://online.businesslink.gov.uk/Growth_and_Innovation_files/QA0024_2011_Awards_InternationalTrade.pdf|title=The Queen's Award For Enterprise Website|accessdate=2011-04-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720081529/https://online.businesslink.gov.uk/Growth_and_Innovation_files/QA0024_2011_Awards_InternationalTrade.pdf#|archive-date=2011-07-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.thecwcgroup.com CWC Group Website]
[[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Training organizations]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date = August 2015}} The '''German education system''' or '''continental education system''' is a [[higher education model]], often contrasted with the [[Anglo-Saxon education system]] and the [[Scandinavian education system]]. It was the standard tertiary education model for most of the countries of [[Continental Europe]] before the implementation of the Anglo-Saxon model there due to the [[Bologna Process]].
A distinction exists between vocational education ([[Fachhochschule]]; i.e.: school of applied sciences) and academic higher education (at university). This is also called [[dual education system]].
In contrast to the Anglo-Saxon model with common lower and higher academic degree for all subjects ([[Bachelor degree]] and [[Master's degree]], respectively), in the German model the degrees are ''[[Diplom]]'' for the more practical subjects such as i.e. [[engineering]], but also [[economics]] and [[business]] and (in [[Germany]] and [[Austria]]) the ''[[Magister Artium]]'' for the more theoretical subjects, such as [[social sciences]] or [[humanities]].
==See also== * [[Higher education policy]] * [[Education in Germany]]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Education in Germany]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{primary sources|date=March 2011}}
'''Curriculum for Excellence''' is the national [[curriculum]] for [[Scottish schools]] for learners from the ages 3-15.
It was developed out of a 2002 consultation exercise – the 'National Debate on Education' – undertaken by the-then [[Scottish Executive]] on the state of school education. In response to the National Debate, Ministers established a Curriculum Review Group in November 2003 to identify the purposes of [[education]] for the 3-18 age range and to determine key principles to be applied in a redesign the curriculum. Its work resulted in the publication in November 2004 of the document ''A Curriculum for Excellence''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Publications/2004/11/20178/45862 |title=A Curriculum For Excellence by the Curriculum Review Group |date=1 November 2004 |publisher=The Scottish Government |accessdate=27 January 2013}}</ref> This document identified four key purposes of education; those that enable young people to become, "successful learners, confident individuals, responsible citizens and effective contributors."
The Curriculum for Excellence was implemented in schools in 2010−11.<ref>[http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/thecurriculum/whatiscurriculumforexcellence/howwasthecurriculumdeveloped/processofchange/timeline.asp Timeline - Process of change - The curriculum in Scotland<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826113301/http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/thecurriculum/whatiscurriculumforexcellence/howwasthecurriculumdeveloped/processofchange/timeline.asp |date=26 August 2014 }}</ref> Its implementation is overseen by [[Education Scotland]].
In Scotland, councils and schools both have some responsibility for what is taught in schools and they must also take national guidelines and advice into account.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-23261286 |title=Why Scotland doesn't have a national curriculum |last=McIvor |first=Jamie |date=10 July 2013 |accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref>
A review was undertaken by the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]], having been commissioned by the Scottish Government to look at the broad general education.<ref name="BBC 15Dec2015">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-35101835 |title=OECD passes judgement on Scotland's Curriculum for Excellence |work=BBC News |date=15 December 2015}}</ref>
==Qualifications== New qualifications were set out in 2014 by the [[Scottish Qualifications Authority]] to meet with the Curriculum for Excellence. The new qualifications are Access 1, Access 2, [[National 3]], [[National 4]], [[National 5]], [[Higher (Scottish)|Higher]] and [[Advanced Higher]] which replaced the former [[Standard Grade]].
==Criticism==
Before its introduction, many within the Scottish teaching profession, including the teachers' trade union [[Educational Institute of Scotland|The Educational Institute of Scotland (EIS)]] and its members,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8039474.stm |title=Union concern at new curriculum |date=8 May 2009 |work=BBC News |accessdate=27 January 2013}}</ref> believed that the Curriculum for Excellence was vague, in particular regarding its supposed 'outcomes and experiences'. There existed a fear that this imprecision would result in a lack of clarity in what was expected of teachers in the classroom and in the assessment of pupils' progress and attainment. At present (January 2013), the Curriculum is in the second school term of its first year of operation, and concerns remain about assessments.
The original concerns led one of the most educationally successful Scottish local authorities, East Renfrewshire, to delay implementation of the secondary school phase of the new curriculum by one year. Some Scottish independent schools, including [[St. Aloysius' College, Glasgow|St Aloysius' College]], in Glasgow, chose to do likewise.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/education/leading-private-school-to-delay-start-of-new-exams.16785920 |title=Leading private school to delay start of new exams |last=Denholm |first=Andrew |date=23 February 2012 |work=The Herald (Glasgow) |accessdate=27 January 2013}}</ref> [[St George's School, Edinburgh|St George's School for Girls]], an independent school in Edinburgh, decided not to adopt the Curriculum for Excellence and offered the [[General Certificate of Secondary Education]] for pupils entering their fourth year (English Year 10) classes from 2013 onwards.
==See also== * [[Education in Scotland]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Education/Schools/curriculum Curriculum for Excellence] on Scottish Government website * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/learning/curriculum_for_excellence.shtml BBC guide] * [http://brightredbooks.net Bright Red Publishing Digital Zone]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Curriculum For Excellence}} [[Category:Curricula]] [[Category:Education in Scotland]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:2002 in education]] [[Category:Standards-based education]] [[Category:Critical pedagogy]] [[Category:Education reform]]
{{Scotland-edu-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = D2L | logo = D2L logo.svg | logo_size = 163px | former_names = Desire2Learn | type = [[Private company|Private]] | industry = Cloud Software: [[Educational technology]] | foundation = 1999 | location_city = [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener, ON]] | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|[[John Baker (entrepreneur)|John Baker]] ([[CEO]])|Jeremy Auger (CSO)|Melissa Howatson ([[Chief financial officer|CFO]])|Cheryl Ainoa(COO)}} | brands = Brightspace | num_employees = 750+ | homepage = [http://www.d2l.com www.D2L.com] | location_country = [[Canada]] }}
'''D2L''', often referred to as '''Desire2Learn''', is a global cloud software company with offices in the United States, Canada, Singapore, Australia, Europe, and Brazil. It is the developer of the Brightspace [[learning management system]] which cloud-based software used by [[school]]s, [[higher education]], and [[business]]es for online and [[Blended learning|blended]] classroom learning.<ref name=edsurge>{{cite web |url=https://www.edsurge.com/n/2014-07-14-the-sum-of-desire2learn-s-acquisitions-brightspace|title=The Sum of Desire2Learn's Acquisitions: Brightspace|date= July 14, 2014|author= Tony Wan|work=Edsurge News }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.betakit.com/desire2learn-launches-new-integrated-learning-platform-called-brightspace/|title=DESIRE2LEARN LAUNCHES NEW INTEGRATED LEARNING PLATFORM CALLED BRIGHTSPACE|date=July 15, 2014|author=JOSEPH CZIKK|work=BetaKit}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thejournal.com/articles/2014/07/14/d2l-intros-revamped-platform-brightspace-with-adaptive-learning.aspx|title=D2L Unveils Revamped Platform 'Brightspace' with Adaptive Learning|author=Dian Schaffhauser|date=2014-07-14|work=THE Journal}}</ref> D2L is also the developer of Open Courses a [[Massive open online course|Massive Open Online Course]] platform.
==History== D2L was founded in 1999 by President and CEO [[John Baker (entrepreneur)|John Baker]] [[Meritorious Service Cross|M.S.C.]] in his third year of [[Systems engineering|Systems Design Engineering]] at the [[University of Waterloo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.txdla.org/documents/EPCspotlight/desire2learn.htm/ |title=EPC Spotlight-Desire2Learn |accessdate=2010-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828054609/http://txdla.org/documents/EPCspotlight/desire2learn.htm |archivedate=August 28, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ic.gc.ca/app/ccc/srch/nvgt.do?lang=eng&prtl=1&estblmntNo=234567068917&profile=cmpltPrfl&profileId=501&app=sold|title=D2L - Complete profile - Canadian Company Capabilities - Industries and Business - Industry Canada|website=www.ic.gc.ca|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref> Today the company has over 750 employees.
In 2004, D2L first introduced support for [[Competency-based learning|Competency Based Education]], and launched an integrated [[Electronic portfolio|ePortfolio]] product to allow learners to document their own learning.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Desire2Learn Supports Educators Striving to Enhance Student Learning Outcomes {{!}} D2L|url = http://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/desire2learn-supports-educators-striving-to-enhance-student-learning-outcomes/|website = D2L|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Desire2Learn Competencies and Rubrics: Part I|url = http://mfeldstein.com/desire2learn-competencies-and-rubrics-functionality-part-i/|website = e-Literate|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = en-US}}</ref>
D2L embraced open standards including SCORM, IMS LTI, IMS Course Packaging, IMS Common Cartridge and IMS Caliper.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/desire2learn-first-to-attain-ims-common-cartridge-compliance-for-learning-management-systems/|title=Desire2Learn First to Attain IMS Common Cartridge Compliance for Learning Management Systems {{!}} Press Release {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/desire2learn-leads-the-way-with-certification-for-ims-basic-learning-tools-interoperability/|title=Desire2Learn Leads the Way with Certification for IMS Basic Learning Tools Interoperability {{!}} Press Release {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/desire2learn-achieves-another-market-first-scorm-2004-certification/|title=Desire2Learn Achieves Another Market First: SCORM 2004 Certification {{!}} Press Release {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/brightspace-autumn15-unlocks-analytics-in-the-classroom/|title=Brightspace Autumn15 Unlocks Analytics in the Classroom {{!}} Press Release {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2011, D2L acquired Captual Technologies Inc.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Desire2Learn acquires small e-learning firm|url = http://www.therecord.com/news-story/2578704-desire2learn-acquires-small-e-learning-firm/|website = www.therecord.com|access-date = 2016-01-14}}</ref> and the technology is now known as Brightspace Capture.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Brightspace Capture {{!}} Brightspace|url = http://www.brightspace.com/products/capture/|website = Brightspace by D2L|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = en-US}}</ref>
In 2012, D2L raised $80 million in financing.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/desire2learn-finally-accepts-venture-investment/article4516924/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | title=Desire2Learn finally accepts venture investment | date=2012-09-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://gigaom.com/2012/09/04/as-ed-tech-heats-up-desire2learn-raises-80m-in-its-first-vc-round/|title=As ed tech heats up, Desire2Learn raises $80M in its first VC round|date= September 4, 2012|author=Ki Mae Heussner|work=Gigaom}}</ref> In the same year, D2L became the recipient of Platinum Learning Impact Award in the event hosted by IMS Global.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imsglobal.org/learningimpact2012/lia2012winners.html|title=Learning Impact 2012 Award Winners {{!}} IMS Global Learning Consortium|website=www.imsglobal.org|access-date=2017-11-01}}</ref>
In 2013, D2L was recognized by the National Federation of the Blind for its leadership in Accessibility with the Dr. ''Jacob Bolotin Award''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nfb.org/national-federation-blind-awards-50000?lang=es|title=National Federation of the Blind Awards $50,000 {{!}} National Federation of the Blind|website=nfb.org|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> In the same year, D2L acquired [[Wiggio]], and Knowillage Systems Inc., the creator of the adaptive learning engine called LeaP.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/03/08/flush-with-80m-desire2learn-buys-anti-sharepoint-for-students-platform-wiggio-its-2nd-acquisition-in-2-months/|title=Flush With $80M, Desire2Learn Buys 'Anti-Sharepoint For Students' Platform Wiggio, Its 2nd Acquisition In 2 Months|date= March 8, 2013 |work=TechCrunch|author1= Ingrid Lunden|author2=Rip Empson }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.edsurge.com/n/2013-03-08-desire2learn-acquires-wiggio|title=Desire2Learn Acquires Wiggio|date=March 8, 2013|work=EdSurge News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/09/09/desire2learn-acquires-knowillage-to-bring-personalized-learning-to-classrooms/|title=Desire2Learn acquires Knowillage to bring personalized learning to classrooms|date=September 9, 2013|author=CHRISTINA FARR|work=VentureBeat}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.techvibes.com/blog/desire2learn-acquires-knowillage-systems-2013-09-09|title=Desire2Learn Goes for Deep Analytics with Acquisition of Knowillage Systems|date=2013-09-09|author=Jacob Serebrin|work=Techvibes}}</ref>
In 2014, D2L raised an $85 million series B financing round.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2014/08/14/desire2learn-raises-85m-to-deliver-personalized-education/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Lora | last=Kolodny | date=2014-08-14 | title=Desire2Learn Raises $85M to Deliver 'Personalized Education'}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/14/canada-tech-desire2learn-idUSL2N0QI2AU20140814 | work=Reuters | title=Canada's Desire2Learn raises $85 mln for global e-learning push | date=2014-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://mobile.bloomberg.com/news/2014-08-14/desire2learn-scores-85-million-in-second-funding-round.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150126151111/http://mobile.bloomberg.com/news/2014-08-14/desire2learn-scores-85-million-in-second-funding-round.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-01-26 |work=Bloomberg |title=Bloomberg Business }}</ref> In the same year, D2L acquired the Achievement Standards Network (ASN) to be an open API and open data system for curriculum standards globally.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Desire2Learn Acquires The Achievement Standards Network From JES & CO|url = http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/desire2learn-acquires-the-achievement-standards-network-from-jes-co-1885167.htm|website = Marketwire|access-date = 2016-01-14}}</ref>
In 2016, D2L was the first and only LMS to partner with the National Federation of the Blind's Strategic Nonvisual Access Partner program to ensure learning systems are fully accessible.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nfb.org/images/nfb/publications/fr/fr36/1/fr360112.htm|title=The Question of Blindfolds|website=nfb.org|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/d2l-partners-national-federation-blind-help-make-learning-accessible/|title=D2L Partners With National Federation of the Blind to Help Make Learning Accessible to All {{!}} Press Release {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
Launched in beta in 2016 and made generally available in early 2017, D2L became the first (academic) LMS to provide full capability on any mobile device using [[responsive web design]] as part of its Daylight User Experience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/d2l-closes-desktop-mobile-gap-summer16-release-classroom-future-finally-hand/|title=D2L Closes the Desktop-Mobile Gap With Summer16 Release -- The Classroom of the Future Is Finally in Hand {{!}} Press Release {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/review/346900/d2l-brightspace-lms|title=D2L Brightspace LMS|website=PCMAG|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref>
==Patent battle== In 2006, D2L and [[Blackboard Inc|Blackboard]] were involved in a legal dispute over issues related to US Patent 6988138.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immagic.com/eLibrary/ARCHIVES/GENERAL/USCOURTS/T060726C.pdf|title=Blackboard Inc. v. Desire2Learn Inc. Complaint}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/federal-circuit-rules-in-favor-of-desire2learn-across-the-board/|title=Federal Circuit Rules in Favor of Desire2Learn Across the Board|accessdate=2010-12-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225102039/http://www.desire2learn.com/news/newsdetails_136.asp|archive-date=2010-12-25|dead-url=no}}</ref> D2L won the patent case on appeal at the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit|Federal Circuit]], and invalidated the patent at the USPTO.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.d2l.com/newsroom/releases/blackboard-desire2learn-announce-patent-cross-license-agreement-and-settlement-of-litigation/|title=Blackboard, D2L Announce Patent Cross License Agreement and Settlement of Litigation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121129003230/http://www.desire2learn.com/news/newsdetails_154.php|archive-date=2012-11-29|dead-url=no|accessdate=2012-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2009/07/27/daily26.html|title=Court rules against Blackboard in patent case|last=Darcy|first=Darlene|date=Jul 27, 2009|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=R5fc140lRJYC&pg=RA33-PA5&lpg=RA33-PA5&dq=d2l+vs+blackboard+uspto+patent+invalidated&source=bl&ots=e7YC22jnXf&sig=sV94ExS6gonCtfnls9eMOO5eTUY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwily8XwtqvXAhWh44MKHb2VDuQQ6AEIQTAE#v=onepage&q=d2l%20vs%20blackboard%20uspto%20patent%20invalidated&f=false|title=USPTO Image File Wrapper Petition Decisions 0492|publisher=USPTO|language=en}}</ref> In December 2009, the companies issued a joint press release indicating that legal proceedings had ended with both companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/blogs/wiredcampus/blackboard-settles-longstanding-patent-fight-with-rival-desire2learn/9229|title=Blackboard Settles Longstanding Patent Fight With Rival Desire2Learn|accessdate=2010-12-14}}</ref>
==Products and services ==
===Brightspace===
D2L's first [[Virtual learning environment|Learning Environment]] clients included [[University of Guelph]], [[Virtual High School (Ontario)|VirtualHighSchool]], and the [[University of Waterloo]].{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} The technology is now used by over 1200 schools, colleges, universities, and businesses around the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/connecting-and-news/cpa-magazine/articles/2015/june/grow-me-the-money|title=Grow me the money|website=www.cpacanada.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref>
Brightspace was built using micro-services and operates as a [[software as a service]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/products/cloud/|title=Brightspace Cloud {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref> It incorporates [[Web Components]] and [[Polymer (library)|Google Polymer]], [[HTML5]], and [[responsive web design]] to provide a modern user interface that can work on any mobile device.
Brightspace combines a [[Virtual learning environment|Learning Environment]], [[Electronic portfolio|ePortfolio]], Learning Repository, Video Recorder, Virtual Classroom, eTextbook platform called Binder, and Mobile apps, in one cloud-based platform.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/products/package/core/|title=Brightspace Core Products & Support {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Engagement Plus=== Engagement Plus combines a cloud-based [[Lecture recording|Lecture Capture]] system, interactive components for engaging course design, and a Course Catelog/Registration System.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/products/package/engagement/|title=Engagement Plus {{!}} Multimedia & Creative Package for Brightspace {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Performance Plus===
Performance Plus is a bundle of [[learning analytics]] to help automate tasks and identify risks. An [[adaptive learning]] engine personalizes the content for each learner. [[Learning analytics|Learning Analytics]] and [[Intelligent agent|Intelligent Agents]] provide early intervention to help learners. And a set of data that can be used to make improvements based upon analysis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/products/package/performance/|title=Performance Plus {{!}} Learner Data & Success Package for Brightspace {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2016, Fast Company recognized D2L as a leader in Data Science.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/company/d2l|title=D2L: Most Innovative Company {{!}} Fast Company|work=Fast Company|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Open Courses=== In 2008, D2L entered the massive open online course MOOC market to support MOOC pioneers Stephen Downes and George Siemens.<ref>http://halfanhour.blogspot.ca/2014/12/open-education-moocs-and-opportunities.html</ref> D2L then launched Open Courses to facilitate experimentation with new pedagogy and develop new ways to reach global learners.
The [[University of Tasmania]] used D2L's MOOC platform to support tens of thousands of learners with >70% of those students starting the courses finishing, bucking the trend of low completion rates in large MOOCs.<ref>http://www.utas.edu.au/wicking/understanding-dementia/data</ref>
===Services=== D2L's services include: cloud-based learning system, end-user help desk support, technical account management, technical data management, advisory consulting, program management, training, course development, customization, and accessibility design support.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.d2l.com/services/|title=eLearning Services {{!}} D2L|work=D2L|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Educational technology]] *[[ePortfolio]] *[[Learning management system]] *[[Virtual learning environment]] *[[Blackboard Inc.#Legal matters|Legal matters section of the Blackboard Inc. article]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.d2l.com}}

revision.comment: removing the word "prominent", also removing a sentence that is a little essay-like
revision.text:
{{Critical pedagogy}} The '''ecopedagogy''' movement is an outgrowth of the theory and practice of [[critical pedagogy]], a body of educational praxis influenced by the philosopher and educator [[Paulo Freire]]. Ecopedagogy's mission is to develop a robust appreciation for the collective potentials of humanity and to foster social justice throughout the world. It does so as part of a future-oriented, ecological and political vision that radically opposes the globalization of ideologies such as [[neoliberalism]] and [[imperialism]], while also attempting to foment forms of critical [[Ecological literacy|ecoliteracy.]] One of ecopedagogy's goals is the realization of culturally relevant forms of knowledge grounded in normative concepts such as [[sustainability]], planetarity (i.e. identifying as an earthling) and biophilia (i.e. love of all life). ==Early history== The ecopedagogy movement began in a Latin American educational context, growing out of discussions at the second [[Earth Summit]], held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in 1992. Educators desired to present a theory and discourse about the interrelationship between society and the environment, a statement would eventually be ratified as the [[Earth Charter]] in 2000. Freire, P. 2000. ''Pedagogia da Terra''. São Paulo, Brazil: Peiropolis. In 1999 the First International Symposium on the Earth Charter in the Perspective of Education was held by the [http://www.paulofreire.org/ Instituto Paulo Freire, Brasil] directed by Moacir Gadotti and in collaboration with the Earth Council and [[UNESCO]]. This was soon followed by the First International Forum on Ecopedagogy. As a result of these conferences, the Ecopedagogy Charter was also formed, launching the spread of ecopedagogy seminars and programs around the world. ==Objectives and aims== Ecopedagogy's primary goal is to create a "planetary consciousness" through revolutionary teaching and learning.{{Cite journal|last=Bowers|first=C.A.|date=2004|title=Revitalizing the Commons or an Individualized Approach to Planetary Citizenship: The Choice Before Us|url=|journal=Educational Studies|volume=36:1|pages=|via=Taylor & Francis}} The movement aims to create educational programs that interrogate the intersection of social, political, economic and environmental systems. As an outgrowth of critical pedagogy, ecopedagogy critiques [[environmental education]] and [[education for sustainable development]] as vain attempts by mainstream forms of pedagogy seeking to appear relevant regarding current issues of environmental degradation. Kahn, Richard. (2008). ''From Education for Sustainable Development to Ecopedagogy: Sustaining Capitalism or Sustaining Life?'' Green Theory & Praxis: The Journal of Ecopedagogy. 4:1 It is critical of mainstream representations of nature that are potentially informed by racist, sexist, and classist values, and wary of the tendency of "[[greenwashing]]" of environmental terminology. Bowers, C.A. 2010. Educational Reforms that Foster Ecological Intelligence. ''Education and the Environment'' Vol. 37, No. 4, pp. 9–31 While members of the ecopedagogy movement recognize that environmental education can accomplish some positive change, they question the ways in which environmental education (especially within global north) is often reduced to forms of experiential pedagogy and [[outdoor education]] without questioning the mainstream experience of nature as pristine wilderness. Ecopedagogy points out that environmental education is often tethered to state and corporate-sponsored science and social studies standards or fails to articulate the political necessity for widespread understanding of the unsustainable nature of modern lifestyles'''.''' However, ecopedagogy has tried to utilize the ongoing United Nations Decade of Educational for Sustainable Development (2005–2015) to make strategic interventions on behalf of the oppressed, using it as an opportunity to unpack and clarify the concept of [[Sustainable development|sustainable development.]] Ecopedagogy scholar Richard Kahn describes the three main goals of the ecopedagogy movement to be: # Creating opportunities for the proliferation of ecoliteracy programs, both within schools and society. # Bridging the gap of praxis between scholars and the public (especially activists) on ecopedagogical interests. # Instigating dialogue and self-reflective solidarity across the many groups among educational left, particularly in light of the existing planetary crisis. Angela Antunes and Moacir Gadotti (2005) write:
"Ecopedagogy is not just another pedagogy among many other pedagogies. It not only has meaning as an alternative project concerned with nature preservation (Natural Ecology) and the impact made by human societies on the natural environment (Social Ecology), but also as a new model for sustainable civilization from the ecological point of view (Integral Ecology), which implies making changes on economic, social, and cultural structures."
According to [[Social movement theory|social movement theorists]] Ron Ayerman and Andrew Jamison, there are three broad dimensions of environmentally related movements: cosmological, technological, and organizational. In ecopedagogy, these dimensions are outlined by Richard Kahn (2010) as the following: * The cosmological dimension focuses on how [[Ecological literacy|ecoliteracy]], i.e. understanding the natural systems that sustain life, can transform people’s worldviews. For example, assumptions about society’s having the right to exploit nature can be transformed into understanding of the need for ecological balance to support society in the long term. The success of such ‘cosmological’ thinking transformations can be assessed by the degree to which such paradigm shifts are adopted by the public. * The technological dimension is two-fold: critiquing the set of polluting technologies that have contributed to traditional development as well as some which are used or misused under the pretext of sustainable development; and promoting clean technologies that do not interfere with ecological and social balance. * The organizational dimension emphasizes that knowledge should be of and for the people, thus academics should be in dialogue with public discourse and social movements. ==Discussion of term in literature== Ecopedagogy is not the collection of theories or practices developed by any particular set of individuals. Rather, akin to the [[World Social Forum]] and other related forms of contemporary popular education strategies, it is a worldwide association of critical educators, theorists, non-governmental and governmental organizations, grassroots activists and concerned citizens who engage in ongoing dialogue and political action. This process attempts to develop ecopedagogical praxis in relation to the needs of particular places, groups and time periods. The earliest use of the term "ecopedagogy" may have been by de Haan (1984) in a now little known German text de Haan, G. 1984. Die Schwierigkeiten der Padagogik. In Beer & de Haan (Eds.), ''Okopadagogik. Aufstehen gegen den Untergang der Natur''. Weinheim, Basel: Beltz: pp. 77–91.. Shortly thereafter, in the first known English use of the term, Gronemeyer (1987) described ecopedagogy as the merging of environmentalist politics and adult education. Gronemeyer, M. 1987. Ecological Education a Failing Practice? Or: Is the Ecological Movement an Educational Movement? In W. Lierman & J. Kulich (Eds.), Adult Education and the Challenge of the 1990s. London: Croom Helm. Ecopedagogy has also been discussed by Ahlberg (1998) Ahlberg, M. 1998. Ecopedagogy and Ecodidactics: Education for Sustainable Development, Good Environment and Good Life. ''Bulletins of the Faculty of Education''. No: 69.University of Joensuu. ; Jardine (2000) Jardine, D. W. 2000. ''“Under the Tough Old Stars”: Ecopedagogical Essays''. Brandon, Vermont: Solomon Press.; Petrina (2000) {{cite journal|last1=Petrina|first1=S|year=2000|title=The Political Ecology of Design and Technology Education: An Inquiry into Methods|url=|journal=International Journal of Technology and Design Education|volume=10|issue=3|pages=207–237|doi=10.1023/a:1008955016067}}; Yang & Hung (2004) {{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=S. K.|last2=Hung|first2=R.|year=2004|title=Towards Construction of an Ecopedagogy Based on the Philosophy of Ecocentrism|url=|journal=Journal of Taiwan Normal University|volume=49|issue=2}}; and Payne (2005) {{cite journal|last1=Payne|first1=P|year=2005|title=Growing Up Green|url=|journal=Journal of the HEIA|volume=12|issue=3|pages=2–12}}. The work of Lummis (2002) {{cite journal|last1=Lummis|first1=G|year=2002|title=Globalisation: Building a Partnership Ethic for an Ecopedagogy in Western Australia|url=|journal=The Australian Journal of Teacher Education|volume=27|issue=1|doi=10.14221/ajte.2002v27n1.2}} shares some sympathies, such as a critical theory approach. Ironically, at the same time it was coined by Freire's friend-cum-critic [[Ivan Illich]] (1988) to describe an educational process in which educators and educands become inscribed in abstract pedagogical systems, resulting in pedagogy as an end and not a means.Illich, I. 1988. Ecopedagogia. ''Alternativas II''. Mexico: Joaquín Mortiz / Planeta. As used by Illich, ecopedagogy is represented by forms of education that seek the total administration of life through mandatory pedagogical experiences of systemization. As such, he believed that the movements for lifelong education and the creation of global classrooms (Illich & Verne, 1981) by bureaucratic educational institutions exemplified such approaches. However, he was also critical of popular environmentalist pedagogy attempting to mobilize people's sentiments for solutions to problems such as global warming, hunger, and rainforest destruction.Illich, I. & E. Verne. 1981. ''Imprisoned in the Global Classroom''. London: Writers & Readers. Illich's point was that such an ecopedagogy works on a problems/solutions axis that implies a global [[managerialism]] that is abhorrent to truly sustainable living in the world. This is a different idea from the way the term and concept is being defined and utilized in critical education circles today, though it is potentially of great importance for the future development of the ecopedagogy movement on the whole. [[Paulo Freire]] was himself at work on a book of ecopedagogy upon his death in 1997, parts of which are included in his posthumous ''Pedagogy of Indignation'' (2004). Freire, P. 2004. ''Pedagogy of Indignation''. Boulder, CO: Paradigm Publishers. Other influential books include: Francisco Gutierrez and Cruz Prado's ''Ecopedagogy and Planetary Citizenship'' (1999), Gutierrez, F. & C. Prado. 1999. ''Ecopedagogia e Cidadania Planetaria''. São Paulo, Brazil: Cortez. Moacir Gadotti's ''Pedagogy of the Earth'' (2000), Gadotti, M. 2003. Pedagogy of the Earth and the Culture of Sustainability. Paper presented at Lifelong Learning, Participatory Democracy and Social Change: Local and Global Perspectives conference, Toronto, Canada. and Richard Kahn's ''Critical Pedagogy, Ecoliteracy, and Planetary Crisis: The Ecopedagogy Movement''. Kahn, Richard. Ecopedagogy: An Introduction. Counterpoints, Vol. 359, Critical Pedagogy, Ecoliteracy, and Planetary Crisis: the Ecopedagogy Movement. (2010), pp. 1–33. == Criticisms == Both supporters and critics of ecopedagogy agree that historically, critical educators in the West have been largely unsuccessful at addressing environmental issues in their classrooms.{{Cite journal|last=McLaren and Houston|first=|date=2005|title=Revolutionary Ecologies: Ecosocialism and Critical Pedagogy|url=|journal=Educational Studies|volume=37:2|pages=|via=}} However, much disagreement still exists between critics and supporters of ecopedagogy on the ethics, theoretical approach, and methodology of this pedagogical style.{{Cite journal|last=Houston, D and McLaren, P.|first=|date=2005|title=The Nature of Political Amnesia: A Response to C.A. 'Chet' Bowers|url=|journal=Educational Studies|volume=|pages=196-214|via=}} One critic, C.A. Bowers, argues that if ecopedagogy (and the larger critical pedagogy of Freire and Gadotti) were universally adopted, it would contribute to the hegemonic spread of Western culture and systems, thereby choking out non-Western ways of thinking, viewing, and interacting with the human and built environments. Bowers further argues that adoption of Freirean ecopedagogy would hasten the existence of a world monoculture and would fail to address the systemic roots of the current ecological crisis and fail to protect the commons from further exploitation.{{Cite journal|last=Bowers|first=C.A.|date=2005|title=How Peter McLaren and Donna Houston, and Other "Green" Marxists Contribute to the Globalization of the West's Industrial Culture|url=|journal=Educational Studies|volume=37:2|pages=185–195|via=}} In this view, ecopedagogy is akin to an educational Trojan horse that is little more than a vehicle for transmitting Western culture and domination. Moderate critics of ecopedagogy argue that the critical lens of ecopedagogy can be useful, but that its adherents must be actively critical of ecopedagogy itself. They argue that without a constant focus on understanding and fostering diversity in thought, culture, and ecosystem, ecopedagogy is meaningless and could be counter-productive to its aims.{{Cite journal|last=Gruenewald|first=David A.|date=2005|title=More than one profound truth: Making sense of divergent criticalities|url=|journal=Educational Studies|volume=|pages=206-214|via=}} Ecopedagogy (and critical pedagogy) has also been heavily criticized for not being critical of the categories that underlie its work. Here, critics argue that in valuing individualism, ecopedagogy fails to attend to traditional eco-centered cultures' already deep connection to the non-human world.{{Cite journal|last=Bowers|first=C.A.|date=2012|title=Questioning the idea of the individual as an autonomous moral agent|url=|journal=Journal of Moral Education|volume=41:3|pages=301-310|via=Routledge}} Moreover, some scholars from the eco- and critical pedagogical traditions fail to recognize how the "primary categories in classical liberal thought may operate in the discourse of critical pedagogy".{{Cite journal|last=Martisewicz|first=Rebecca|date=2005|title=On Acknowledging Differences that Make a Difference: My Two Cents|url=|journal=Educational Studies|volume=|pages=215-224|via=}} == Ecopedagogy in action == Ecopedagogy emphasizes the necessity of praxis alongside theory. Gaard, G. (2009). ''Children’s environmental literature: from ecocriticism to ecopedagogy.'' Neohelicon 36:321–334. Besides the specific ecopedagogy degree programs and Paulo Freire Institutes, there are many instances of ecological education that not only teach people the critical thinking of ecopedagogy but also engage them in learning through action. For example, a study conducted with 10-year-old children in West Scotland concluded that interactive dramatic education was successful in engaging students in ecological, social, and political dimensions of global problems such as solid waste and deforestation.McNaughton, M.J. (2010). ''Educational drama in education for sustainable development: ecopedagogy in action.'' Pedagogy, Culture & Society. 18:3, 289-308. The dramatic exercises required to make a decision or take a stance, thus strengthening their understanding and conviction of the issues. And ecopedagogy is not limited to formal students; in Turkey, for example, participatory action research showed that an outdoor community-based ecopedagogy program for university professors was successful in the "promotion of public participation, the engagement of students, teacher and parents in local environmental issues, and the development of social capital to achieve environmental sustainability. By situating local knowledge within critical pedagogy and social activism, these projects can help universities to bridge the gap between academia and society."Mustafa, Y.U. et al. (2010). A Participatory Action Research Study of Nature Education in Nature: Towards Community-based Eco-pedagogy. International Journal of Progressive Education. 6:3. Greta Gaard outlines the necessity for children's environmental literature to encompass the following core aspects of ecopedagogy: * praxis * teaching ABOUT the social and natural environment * teaching IN the social and natural environment * teaching THROUGH the social and natural environment * teaching the connections of sustainability * urgency The question of technology had become increasingly pertinent. Kahn, Richard. Technological Transformation as Ecopedagogy: Reconstructing Technoliteracy. Counterpoints, Vol. 359, Critical Pedagogy, Ecoliteracy, and Planetary Crisis: the Ecopedagogy Movement. (2010), pp. 61–80 While the production and consumption of technology largely has a negative effect on the environment and certain aspects of society-environment relations, technology still provides certain new avenues in ecopedagogy. For example, more people have access to information and collaboration through the internet and thus can engage in informal ecological education faster and in wider spheres. Similarly, community projects to install solar panels or wind turbines or simple technology that help farms to transition to agroecology are examples of the uses of technology in ecopedagogy. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Additional sources== * Grigorov, S. 2012. International Handbook of Ecopedagogy for Students, Educators and Parents. A Project for a New Eco-Sustainable Civilization. BCSLDE, Sofia. Free for download at: www.bcslde.org * Grigorov, S & Fleuri, R. 2012. Ecopedagogy: educating for a new eco-social intercultural perspective. Visão Global, UNOESC, Florianopolis. Free for download at: http://editora.unoesc.edu.br/index.php/visaoglobal/article/view/3435/1534 and https://www.academia.edu/4111655/Grigorov_S_and_Fleuri_R._2012._Ecopedagogy_educating_for_a_new_eco-social_intercultural_perspective._Visao_Global_UNOESC_Florianopolis *Kahn, R. 2010. [https://antiochla.academia.edu/RichardKahn/Papers/173263/Love_Hurts_Ecopedagogy_Between_Avatars_and_Elegies Love Hurts: Ecopedagogy Between Avatars and Elegies]. ''Teacher Education Quarterly'', Vol. 37, No. 4 (Fall). *Kahn, R. 2009. [https://und.academia.edu/RichardKahn/attachment/102617/full/Producing-Crisis--Green-Consumerism-as-an-Ecopedagogical-Issue Producing Crisis: Green Consumerism as an Ecopedagogical Issue]. In J. Sandlin and P. McLaren (Eds.), ''Critical Pedagogies of Consumption: Living and Learning Beyond the Shopocalypse''. New York: Routledge. *Kahn, R. 2008. [https://und.academia.edu/RichardKahn/Papers/72002/Towards-Ecopedagogy--Weaving-a-Broad-based-Pedagogy-of-Liberation-for-Animals--Nature-and-the-Oppressed-Peoples-of-the-Earth Towards Ecopedagogy: Weaving a Broad-based Pedagogy of Liberation for Animals, Nature and the Oppressed Peoples of the Earth]. In A. Darder, R. Torres and M. Baltodano (Eds.), ''The Critical Pedagogy Reader'' (2nd ed.). New York: Routledge. *Kahn, R. 2007. ''The Ecopedagogy Movement: From Global Ecological Crisis to Cosmological, Technological and Organizational Transformation in Education''. Doctoral Dissertation (Committee: [[Douglas Kellner]], Chair; [[Peter McLaren]]; and [[Steven Best]]), Graduate School of Education & Information Studies, University of California, Los Angeles. *{{cite journal | last1 = Kahn | first1 = R | year = 2006 | title = The Educative Potential of Ecological Militancy in an Age of Big Oil: Towards a Marcusean ecopedagogy | doi = 10.2304/pfie.2006.4.1.31 | journal = Policy Futures in Education | volume = 4 | issue = 1| pages = 31–44 }} *{{cite journal | last1 = Magalhaes | first1 = H. G. D. | year = 2005 | title = Ecopedagogia y Utopia | url = | journal = Educação Temática Digital, Campinas | volume = 7 | issue = 1| pages = 53–60 }} [[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Critical pedagogy]] [[Category:Environmental education]]

revision.text:
'''Education in [[Montserrat]]''' is compulsory for children between the ages of 5 and 14, and free up to the age of 17.<ref name="ilab">{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/tda2001/territories.htm |chapter=Territories and Non-Independent Countries |title=2001 Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor |publisher=[[Bureau of International Labor Affairs]], [[US Department of Labor]] |year=2002 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050328070122/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/tda2001/territories.htm |archivedate=March 28, 2005}} ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].</ref> The Government of Montserrat developed an Education in the Country Policy Plan for 1998–2002 in conjunction with the United Kingdom.<ref name=ilab/> Under this plan, the government is supporting initiatives in the areas of curriculum development, student assessment and evaluation, professional development for teachers, post-secondary education expansion, and educational infrastructure and information technology.<ref name=ilab/>
The educational system is similar to [[Education in England|that of England]].<ref name=Propp68>"[https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/57a08b41e5274a27b2000a55/TI_UP_Consultancy_Jan2009_Development_Proposals_for_Schools_in_Montserrat.pdf Development Proposals for: Lookout Primary School Brades Primary School Montserrat Secondary School 2008 MNT 09]." [[Department for International Development UK]]. p. 68 (in "ANNEX 1: TERMS OF REFERENCE: DESIGN CONSULTANCY FOR EDUCATION INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAMME") (PDF p. 71/73). Retrieved on November 24, 2017.</ref> In 1990 all primary school-aged residents were enrolled in school.<ref>''Ministries of Education in Small States: Case Studies of Organisation and Management''. [[Commonwealth Secretariat]], 1991. {{ISBN|0850923670}}, 9780850923674. p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=OgY9dnWO4OAC&pg=PA163 163].</ref>
==History== {{expand section|date=November 2017}} Methodists created two schools, one each in Plymouth and Cavalla Hill. The Sturges family founded the Olveston School.<ref>''Three (3) papers on the educational system in Montserrat''. [[Government Information Unit (Montserrat)]], 1986. p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=5ZoQAAAAYAAJ&q=Montserrat+Plymouth+%22primary+school%22&dq=Montserrat+Plymouth+%22primary+school%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiNzaTP497XAhWFT98KHRbHDzIQ6AEIQDAF 1].</ref>
==Schools== Government daycares include Lookout Daycare, St. John's Daycare, and Salem Daycare. Government nurseries include Brades Nursery, Lookout Nursery, and Salem Nursery. Aunt Madge Child Care, a private institution, has nursery and daycare services.<ref name=Digest2014p2>"[http://www.gov.ms/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Education-Statistical-Digest-of-Montserrat-2013-2014-1.pdf Statistical Digest 2014]." [[Ministry of Education Montserrat]]. p. 2-3 (PDF p. 7-8/27). Retrieved on November 28, 2017.</ref> Lookout Nursery opened in 2001, Lookout Daycare opened in 2002, and Salem Nursery opened in 2005. St. John's Nursery closed in 2001.<ref name=Caribankp106>"[http://www.caribank.org/uploads/2012/12/Montserrat-2009-vol-1_v7.pdf Montserrat Survey of Living Conditions, 2009 Volume 1, Main Report]." Government of Montserrat and the [[Caribbean Development Bank]]. December 2012. Retrieved on November 28, 2017. p. 106 (PDF p. 150/204).</ref>
There are two government primary schools with Kindergarten and grades 1-6:<ref name=Propp3>"[https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/57a08b41e5274a27b2000a55/TI_UP_Consultancy_Jan2009_Development_Proposals_for_Schools_in_Montserrat.pdf Development Proposals for: Lookout Primary School Brades Primary School Montserrat Secondary School 2008 MNT 09]." [[Department for International Development UK]]. p. 3 (PDF p. 6/73). Retrieved on November 24, 2017.</ref> * Brades Primary School ([[Brades]]) ** The [[Methodist Church]] built the school in 1966. Further additions and renovation were done by the Montserrat government.<ref name=Propp4>"[https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/57a08b41e5274a27b2000a55/TI_UP_Consultancy_Jan2009_Development_Proposals_for_Schools_in_Montserrat.pdf Development Proposals for: Lookout Primary School Brades Primary School Montserrat Secondary School 2008 MNT 09]." [[Department for International Development UK]]. p. 4 (PDF p. 7/73). Retrieved on November 24, 2017.</ref> In 2009 the school was overpopulated;<ref name=Schools>"[https://www.gov.uk/dfid-research-outputs/development-proposals-for-lookout-primary-school-brades-primary-school-montserrat-secondary-school-2008-mnt-09 Development proposals for: Lookout Primary School, Brades Primary School, Montserrat Secondary School, 2008 MNT 09.]"</ref> it had 151 students that year.<ref name=Propp4/> * Lookout Primary School (Lookout) **It was established after the 1997 [[Soufrière Hills#1995–1999 eruption|Soufrière Hills volcanic eruption]],<ref name=Schools/> beginning as a secondary institution in 1997. In 2001 it was converted into a primary institution. There are three buildings, with Building 1 at the highest-most point. In 2009 it had 174 students.<ref name=Propp3/>
There are two private primary schools with Kindergarten and grades 1-6:<ref name=Propp68/> * St. Augustine Catholic Primary School (Brades)<ref>[http://www.staugustine.ms/ Home page]. St. Augustine Catholic Primary School. Retrieved on November 24, 2017. "ST. AUGUSTINE CATHOLIC PRIMARY SCHOOL Palm Loop, Montserrat P.O. Box 192, Brades MSR 1110"</ref> * Lighthouse Primary School<ref name=Digest2014p2/> * Samuel Academy (opened 2005)<ref name=Caribankp106/>
Thee is also a Special Needs Unit primary school which opened in 2003.<ref name=Caribankp106/>
The only [[secondary school]] (pre-16 years of age) on the island is the [[Montserrat Secondary School]] (MSS), a government-operated school in [[Salem, Montserrat|Salem]].<ref name=Propp3/> [[Montserrat Community College]] (MCC) is a [[community college]] (post-16 and tertiary) in Salem.<ref>[http://www.mcc.ms/ Home page]. [[Montserrat Community College]]. Retrieved on November 24, 2017. "Salem, Montserrat W. I."</ref> MCC took over [[sixth-form college]] from MSS upon its opening in 2004.<ref name="MCCHist"/>
The [[University of the West Indies]] maintains its Montserrat Open Campus.<ref>"[http://www.open.uwi.edu/montserrat The Open Campus in Montserrat]." [[University of the West Indies]] Open Campus. Retrieved on November 24, 2017.</ref> The [[University of Science, Arts and Technology]] in [[Olveston, Montserrat|Olveston]], a private tertiary institution, was established in 2003 and is accredited by [[Ministry of Education (Montserrat)|Montserrat's Ministry of Education]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usat.ms/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 16, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929033304/http://www.usat.ms/ |archivedate=September 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===Pre-1997=== {{expand section|date=November 2017}} In the pre-1997 era, Montserrat had state, private, and church schools. In 1989 the island had two day care centres. Its 12 nursery schools had 460 students in 1988. Its 12 primary schools had 1,403 students in 1988.<ref name=Hunterp968>Hunter, Brian (editor). ''The Statesman's Year Book: 1992–93'' (29th edition). [[Springer Science+Business Media]], December 29, 2016. {{ISBN|0230271219}}, 9780230271210. p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=OaXPDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA968 968].</ref> * Kinsdale Primary School (KPS)<ref name=Thomasp279>Thomas, Emel (editor). ''Education in the Commonwealth Caribbean and Netherlands Antilles''. [[Bloomsbury Publishing]], May 8, 2014. {{ISBN|1623563836}}, 9781623563837. p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=yqlQAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA279 279].</ref> ** It served as a hurricane shelter.<ref>Miller, Paul. ''School Leadership in the Caribbean: Perceptions, Practices, Paradigms''. [[Symposium Books Ltd]], 6 May 2013. {{ISBN|1873927819}}, 9781873927816. p. [https://books.google.de/books?id=yKFwCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA37 37].</ref> * [[Plymouth, Montserrat|Plymouth]] Primary School<ref name=Thomasp279/> * Salem Primary School<ref name=MCCHist>"[http://www.mcc.ms/about/history/history.html History]." [[Montserrat Community College]]. Retrieved on November 27, 2017.</ref>
Prior to 1928 residents had to go outside Montserrat to get secondary schooling. In 1928, the first secondary institution, Montserrat Boys Grammar School, a government boys-only school, opened. In 1932 a private girls-only secondary school opened. They merged into MSS in 1938.<ref name="mssassociation">{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131125232908/http://www.mssassociation.org/about-us|publisher=mssassociation.org|title=ABOUT US | MSS ASSOCIATION|accessdate=2017-02-18}}</ref>
In the pre-1997 era, Plymouth Junior Secondary School, Salem Junior Secondary School,<ref>"[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0006/000619/061941eb.pdf Report of the Technical-Vocational Education and Training Reconnaissance Mission]." [[UNESCO]]. Annex 1 p. 2 (PDF p. 12/14). Retrieved on 27 November 2017.</ref> and the MSS junior section had lower secondary education while MSS senior section had upper secondary education.<ref>"[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0006/000619/061941eb.pdf Report of the Technical-Vocational Education and Training Reconnaissance Mission]." [[UNESCO]]. Annex 1 p. 3 (PDF p. 13/14). Retrieved on 27 November 2017.</ref> They were branches of one secondary institution, and together had 1,043 students in 1988.<ref name=Hunterp968/>
There was also a [[technical college]], Montserrat Technical College (MTC),<ref name=Thomasp279/> with 72 students in 1988.<ref name=Hunterp968/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gov.ms/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/Curriculum-Delivery-of-Montserrats-Primary-and-Secondary-Schools-Report-2012.pdf Review of Montserrat's Primary and Secondary Schools' Organisation and Instructional Practices in Curriculum Delivery] - [[Government of Montserrat]] - 2012 {{Montserrat topics}} {{Education in North America}}
[[Category:Education in Montserrat| ]]
{{Montserrat-stub}} {{education-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox education in country | country name = Papua New Guinea | agency image = [[File:National_Emblem_of_Papua_New_Guinea.svg|250px]] | agency = Department of Education | leader titles = | leader names = | budget = 1242.8 million PGK [http://www.pwc.com/pg/en/budget-commentary/assets/2017%20PwC%20Budget%20Commentary.pdf "Papua New Guinea 2017 National Budget"] pwc.com. Retrieved June 14, 2017. | budget year = 2016 | funding per student = | primary languages = [[English language|English]], [[Tok Pisin]], [[Hiri Motu]] and [[Languages of Papua New Guinea|others]] | system type = Public, religious, private | established events = | established dates = | literacy year = 2015 est | literacy total = 64.2% [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pp.html "The World Factbook"] cia.gov. Retrieved June 14, 2017. | literacy men = 65.6% | literacy women = 62.8% | enrollment year = 2014 | enroll total = 1,805,000 [https://www.epdc.org/sites/default/files/documents/EPDC%20NEP_Papua%20New%20Guinea.pdf "Papua New Guinea National Education Profile"] Education Policy And Data Center. Retrieved August 23, 2017. | enroll primary = 1,427,000 | enroll secondary = 243,000 (Lower)
136,000 (Upper) | enroll post-secondary = | attainment year = | attain secondary = | attain post-secondary = | footnotes = }} '''Education in Papua New Guinea''' is managed through '''nineteen [[Provinces of Papua New Guinea|provinces]] and two district organisational units'''. It is tuition-free and attendance is not compulsory. With a literacy rate of 64.2%, [[Papua New Guinea]] has the lowest literacy rate in [[Oceania]]. ==History== The first school in Papua New Guinea was established in 1873 by English missionaries. Missionaries would continue providing the basis for education, with [[English language|English]] and [[German language|German]] as primary languages. In 1914, as part of World War I, Australia took control over German New Guinea and English became the sole official language. The Currie Commission was created in 1964 to investigate the establishment of higher education in the [[Territory of Papua and New Guinea]]. In 1965 the first university in Papua New Guinea, the [[University of Papua New Guinea]], was established. It was heavily influenced by the Australian education system. Richard Guy, Toshio Kosuge, Rieko Hayakawa (2000). ''Distance Education in the South Pacific: Nets and Voyages''. Institute of Pacific Studies, University of the South Pacific and Pacific Island Nations Fund, Sasakawa Peace Foundation. p. 115 Education in Papua New Guinea has been tuition-free since 2012, as one of the election promises of the [[People's National Congress (Papua New Guinea)|People's National Congress]]. ==Provision== Papua New Guinea's history of missionary education has led to a large part of education being provided by religious schools. The Department of Education has estimated that 29% of the country's lower secondary education is operated by churches. 3% is operated by private international schools, while the remainder is funded by the government. ==Educational Stages== Papua New Guinea has an A-to-D grading system, with D being a failing grade. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+Education[https://www.classbase.com/Countries/Papua-New-Guinea/Education-System "Papua New Guinea Education System"] classbase.com. Retrieved November 08, 2017. |- !Age ! colspan="2" | Level !School !Language |- |7 | rowspan="2" colspan="2" | Introductory | rowspan="8" | Local community school | rowspan="8" | Local languages |- |8 |- |9 | rowspan="4" colspan="2" | Primary |- |10 |- |11 |- |12 |- |13 | rowspan="4" colspan="2" | Middle |- |14 |- |15 | rowspan="2" | Provincial high school | rowspan="8" | Official languages
(English, Tok Pisin, Hiri Motu) |- |16 |- |17 | rowspan="2" | Secondary | rowspan="3" | Vocational
(duration varies) | rowspan="2" | National high school |- |18 |- |19+ |Tertiary |University |} ==Universities== {{See also|List of schools in Papua New Guinea#Universities and tertiary education}} There are six universities in Papua New Guinea. These are accredited under the PNG Office of Higher Education and have establishing Acts of Parliament. The six universities and the main campus of each are, in alphabetical order: *Divine Word University in Madang *Pacific Adventist University in Port Moresby *University of Goroka in Goroka *University of Natural Resources and Environment in Vudal with associated campuses in Popondetta, Kavieng and Sepik *University of Papua New Guinea in Port Moresby *University of Technology (Unitech) in Lae ==Language education== In 2015, [[Papua New Guinean Sign Language]] became an official language in PNG. Based on [[Auslan]], it is used in [[deaf education]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Oceania topic|Education in}} [[Category:Education in Papua New Guinea| ]] {{PapuaNewGuinea-stub}} {{Edu-stub}}

revision.comment: Quote parameter activated, substantiating the "first school bus operator to integrate Zonar" claim.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Bus transit | name = First Student | logo = First Student logo.png | logo_size = 195 | image =ICCE First Student Wallkill School Bus.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = | company_slogan = | parent = [[FirstGroup]] | founded = 1999
(through acquisition of school bus business of [[Ryder]]) | headquarters = 600 Vine Street, Ste. 1400
[[Cincinnati, Ohio]] 45202 | locale = | service_area = United States | service_type = [[School bus]], charter service | alliance = | routes = | destinations = | stops = | hubs = | stations = | lounge = | fleet = 49,000 (March 2016) | ridership = | fuel_type = | operator = | ceo = | leader_type = | leader = | website = {{URL|www.firststudentinc.com}} }} '''First Student''', a division of [[FirstGroup|FirstGroup America]], is a brand used by the Scottish transport company [[FirstGroup]] for [[student transport]] in the United States. According to the company's website, it is the largest provider of [[School bus contractor|school bus services]] in the United States. The company operates out of 650 locations in 39 US states and eight [[Provinces and territories of Canada|Canadian province]]s.[http://www.firststudentinc.com/about First Student in a snapshot] First Student With a workforce of 57,000 employees and a fleet of 48,000 vehicles, First Student transports approximately 6 million students daily. The company bus fleet drives over 600 million miles every year. First Student is the first school bus operator to integrate [[Zonar Systems|Zonar]], an [[fleet management|electronic fleet-management software]] program, into its fleet.{{cite press release |title=First Student To Equip Entire Fleet of 60,000 Vehicles With Zonar |url=http://www.firststudentinc.com/about/newsroom/2010/05/01/first-student-to-equip-entire-fleet-of-60-000-vehicles-with-zonar |website=www.firststudentinc.com |language=en |date=1 May 2010|quote=''...first as a pilot customer...''}} == Company history == {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} First Student was created in 1999 when [[FirstGroup]] acquired the student transportation division of [[Ryder]]. During the next decade, the company expanded through the acquisition of other school bus contractors. By 2007, FirstGroup had built the First Student network into one of the largest school bus contractors in the United States, and in the same year, the company acquired [[Laidlaw]] in a merger, taking over its school transportation operations as well. The First Student brand has since been expanded into the [[United Kingdom|UK]], where [[First Student (United Kingdom)|First Student UK]] provides new student transportation services. One bus has toured the country{{which|date=October 2018}} on trials.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/nol/newsid_6290000/newsid_6294300/6294362.stm?bw=bb&mp=wm&news=1&nol_storyid=6294362&bbcws=1 BBC News Video - "Bus boss explains yellow buses"] Accessed 22 July 2008 ==See also== *[[First Student Canada]] *[[First Student UK]] *[[Laidlaw]] *[[FirstGroup]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category-inline|First Student buses}} *[http://www.firststudentinc.com/ Corporate website] {{FirstGroup|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Companies based in Cincinnati]] [[Category:First Group companies]] [[Category:School bus operators]] [[Category:Student transport]] [[Category:Transport companies established in 1999]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Ohio]]

revision.comment: readability: "all but" -> "almost"; see [[plain English]]
revision.text:
[[File:Free body frictionless.svg|right|300px|thumb|Key:
N = [[normal force]] that is perpendicular to the plane
m = [[mass]] of object
g = acceleration due to [[gravity]]
θ ([[theta]]) = angle of elevation of the plane, measured from the horizontal]] The '''frictionless plane''' is a concept from the writings of [[Galileo Galilei]]. In his 1608 ''[[Two_New_Sciences#Day_3_Naturally_accelerated_motion|The Two New Sciences]]'', Galileo presented a formula that predicted the motion of an object moving down an [[inclined plane]]. His formula was based upon his past experimentation with free-falling bodies.Drake, Stillman, ''Galileo’s Experimental Confirmation of Horizontal Inertia: Unpublished Manuscripts.'' ''Isis'': Vol. 64, No. 3, p. 296. However, his model was not based upon experimentation with objects moving down an inclined plane, but from his conceptual modeling of the forces acting upon the object. Galileo understood the mechanics of the inclined plane as the combination of horizontal and vertical [[Vector (geometric)|vectors]]; the result of [[gravity]] acting upon the object, diverted by the [[slope]] of the plane.Settle, T. B. "An Experiment in the History of Science", ''Science'', 1061 ''133'' 19–23. However, Galileo's equations do not contemplate [[friction]], and therefore do not perfectly predict the results of an actual [[experiment]]. This is because some energy is always lost when one mass applies a non-zero [[normal force]] to another. Therefore, the observed [[speed]], [[acceleration]] and distance traveled should be less than Galileo predicts. Jenkin, Fleeming. ''On Friction Between Surfaces at Low Speeds.'' Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Vol. 26 p. 93–94 This energy is lost in forms like sound and heat. However, from Galileo's predictions of an object moving down an inclined plane in a frictionless environment, he created the theoretical foundation for extremely fruitful real-world experimental prediction.Drake, at p. 297–99 Frictionless planes do not exist in the real world. However, if they did, one can be almost certain that objects on them would behave exactly as Galileo predicts. Despite their nonexistence, they have considerable value in the design of engines, motors, roadways, and even tow-truck beds, to name a few examples. Koyré, Alexandre ''Metaphysics and Measurement'', pp. 83–84 (1992). The effect of friction on an object moving down an inclined plane can be calculated as : F_\mathrm{f} = \mu_\mathrm{k} F_\mathrm{N}, where F_\mathrm{f} is the force of friction exerted by the object and the inclined plane on each other, parallel to the surface of the plane, F_\mathrm{N} is the [[normal force]] exerted by the object and the plane on each other, directed perpendicular to the plane, and \mu_\mathrm{k} is the coefficient of [[Friction#Kinetic_friction|kinetic friction]]. Koyré, pp. 84–86. Unless the inclined plane is in a [[vacuum]], a (usually) small amount of [[potential energy]] is also lost to [[air drag]]. ==See also== *[[Atwood machine]] *[[Spherical cow]] == References == [[Category:Abstraction]] [[Category:Physics education]]

revision.text:
The '''Grundtvig programme''' is a European funding programme that is part of the [[European Commission]]’s [[Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2013]]<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/index_en.html European Commission - The Lifelong Learning Programme 2007-2013] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130319090812/http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/llp/index_en.html |date=2013-03-19 }}</ref> and aims to strengthen the European dimension in adult education and lifelong learning across Europe.
The programme specifically seeks to address the educational challenge of an ageing population and to provide adults with alternative pathways to updating their skills and competences. The Grundtvig programme encompasses all types of learning, whether these take place in the 'formal' or 'non-formal' system of education for adults, or in more 'informal' ways, such as autonomous learning, community learning or experiential learning.
It is open to anyone in adult education. This includes adult learners, teachers and trainers from a variety of organisations including local authorities, non-governmental organisations, charities, universities, community groups, etc. 'Adult' in the Grundtvig programme refers to all persons over the age of 25 and all persons aged 16–24 who are no longer undergoing initial education within the formal education system.
The Grundtvig programme provides funding for a wide range of activities. Some examples are basic skills, foreign languages, parental education, arts and culture projects. All projects involve working with European partners and offer a learning and personal development experience for staff and learners.
== Examples of Grundtvig programme projects == *[http://letsdoit.upol.cz/ Let's do it creatively for the benefit of adult learners (2009-2011)] *[http://letsdoit.citym.ro/ Let's Do It Creatively ... and Environmentally with Renewable Energy (2011-2013)] *[http://joyar.aidorg.ro/ JoyAR: Joyful Adult Training Using Augmented Reality (2012-2014)] *[http://www.literacy-project.com/project/ Adult Literacy: Grundtvig Adult literacy from creating joyful learning experience into active citizenship (2013 - 2015)]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130730072946/http://ec.europa.eu/education/programmes/newprog/index_en.html European Union — The Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2015] *[http://www.lifelonglearningprogramme.org.uk/index.asp UK - The Lifelong Learning Programme 2007-2013] *[http://www.grundtvig.org.uk/ UK - Grundtvig programme] *[http://www.naep.cz/?language=en&/ Czech republic - The National Agency for European Educational Programmes] *[http://www.volunteers-in-parks.eu/?language=en&/ EU-GRUNDTVIG Project Volunteer Management in European Parks]
[[Category:Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union]] [[Category:Adult education]] [[Category:Lifelong learning]] [[Category:Education in Europe]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} '''Henry C. Groseclose''' was born on May 17, 1892.<ref name="The HMDB">{{cite web|last=Prats|first=J.J|title=Henry C. Groseclose|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=44219|publisher=The Historical Marker Database|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> He lived in Ceres, Virginia for most of his life.<ref name="The HMDB" /> Mr. Groseclose completed his junior college degree from [[Washington and Lee University]] in 1917.<ref name=agedteachers>{{cite web|last=Hillson|first=John|title=The Role of Agricultural Education Teacher Educator Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow|url=http://pubs.aged.tamu.edu/jae/pdf/vol39/39-01-01.pdf|publisher=pubs.aged.tamu.edu|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref> In his later years, he also received his [[bachelor’s degree]], as well as his [[master’s degree]], in [[agricultural education]] from [[Virginia Tech]].<ref name="agedteachers"/> While Mr. Groseclose was an agriculture teacher at the [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute]], he, along with three other agriculture teachers, [[Walter Stephenson Newman|Walter Newman]], [[Edmund Magill]] and [[Harry Sanders]], decided to establish a club for the farm boys in the school. The organization was formed in 1925.<ref name="The HMDB" /> Groseclose named the organization the [[Future Farmers of Virginia]], or FFV for short.<ref name=VirginiaRole>{{cite web|last=Hillson|first=John|title=The Role of Virginia in the Development of the FFA|url=http://pubs.aged.tamu.edu/jae/pdf/vol34/34-02-37.pdf|publisher=pubs.aged.tamu.edu|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref>
The original meaning for the abbreviation FFV stood for the [[First Families of Virginia]].<ref name="VirginiaRole"/> The “first families” referred to the families of both [[George Washington]] and [[Thomas Jefferson]].<ref name="VirginiaRole"/> Referring to Washington and Jefferson, Groseclose once stated that, “The Future Farmers of America should follow the example of these great sons of early Virginia by using scientific knowledge, intelligence, and enthusiasm to the end that agriculture may again be known as the profession of the real aristocrat.”<ref name=AgriculturalSocieties>{{cite web |last1=Hillson |first1=John |title=Agricultural Societies as Antecedents of the FFA |url=http://pubs.aged.tamu.edu/jsaer/pdf/Vol51/51-00-102.pdf |publisher=pubs.aged.tamu.edu |accessdate=4 June 2013|author2=Bryant, Brad}}</ref> Groseclose wrote the by-laws, as well as the constitution that the FFV would be based on.<ref name="VirginiaRole"/>
In 1926, he also wrote, and brought into play, the formal ceremony that would take place as an organizational pattern to structure each meeting.<ref name="AgriculturalSocieties"/> Two years later, in 1928, the FFV became a nationwide organization. This developed the organization that is known today as the Future Farmers of America, or The [[National FFA Organization]], or just FFA for short. The by-laws drawn up by Henry Groseclose became the foundation of the newly national organization.<ref name="VirginiaRole"/> Also, the formal ceremony that Groseclose developed was taken on by the FFA as a national ritual that is still used today.<ref name="AgriculturalSocieties"/> Groseclose was a seventh degree [[The National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry|Grange]] member,<ref name="AgriculturalSocieties"/> and he was also involved with the [[Free mason|Masons]], so it was no surprise when he developed levels of memberships for the FFV, which transferred through to the FFA, that were similar to the three leveled membership structure that the Masons uses. These three levels included the Greenhand, the Virginia Farmer and the Virginia Planter.<ref name="VirginiaRole"/>
While the official emblem of the National FFA Organization was being drawn, Groseclose’s original emblem, which he hand drew himself, was highly considered and ended up playing a part in the emblem that is still the emblem of the National FFA Organization today.<ref name=VirginiaFFA>{{cite web|last=Virginia Association of Agricultural Educators and FFA Alumni|title=Virginia's Role in the Development of the FFA|url=http://www.vaffa.org/History/VirginiaFFA.html|publisher=Virginia FFA|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> The part of the emblem that was from Mr. Groseclose’s original drawing included a background setting of a half [[plow]]ed wheat field with an [[owl]] perched upon a spade of wheat in front of the field.<ref name="VirginiaFFA"/>
Henry Groseclose served as the Executive Secretary of the National FFA Organization for two years between 1928 and 1930.<ref name="The HMDB" /> During his office of Executive Secretary, he announced at the national convention of 1930 that he had written, and would be releasing, an official FFA manual, which outlined the organization, procedures and structures of the National FFA Organization.<ref name="Historical Review">{{cite web|last1=Hoover|first1=Tracy|title=A Historical Review of Leadership Development in the FFA and 4-H|url=http://www.jae-online.org/attachments/article/167/Hoover_etal_48_3_100-110.pdf|publisher=jae-online|accessdate=4 June 2013|author2=Scholl, Jan}}</ref> Mr. Groseclose also served as the Treasurer of the National FFA Organization for 11 years, between 1930 and 1941.<ref name="The HMDB" />
In September 1925, Henry Groseclose set his expectations for the members of the FFV, and the purpose of the establishment of the Future Farmers of Virginia was by saying, "In my opinion the farm boys of Virginia who are enrolled in vocational agriculture are equal to any other group of boys in the state. But somehow the boys themselves seem to have a feeling of inferiority. Especially is this true when the farm boy goes to the city and has to compete with his city cousin. This condition should not exist. I believe that a strong organization of our boys in agriculture would help them to overcome this handicap. Let's form an organization that will give them a greater opportunity for self-expression and for the development of leadership. In this way they will develop confidence in their own ability and pride in the fact that they are farm boys."<ref name=HistoryofFFA>{{cite web|last=Virginia Association of Agricultural Educators and FFA Alumni|title=History of the FFA|url=http://www.vaffa.org/History/History.html|publisher=Virginia FFA|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> Mr. Henry C. Groseclose died on June 4, 1950.<ref name="The HMDB" /> In 2002, the [[Department of Historic Resources]] established a marker in Mr. Groseclose’s honor. It is Marker number KC-5 and it is displayed in [[Bland County, Virginia|Bland County]] of [[Ceres, Virginia]].<ref name="The HMDB" />
==Time Line== *'''1892''' Born<ref name="The HMDB" /> *'''1917''' Completed junior college degree<ref name=agedteachers /> *'''1925''' Established the FFV<ref name="The HMDB" /> *'''1926''' Formal ceremony written<ref name=AgriculturalSocieties /> *'''1928''' Formation of the National FFA Organization *'''1928-1930''' Service as National FFA Executive Secretary<ref name="The HMDB" /> *'''1930-1941''' Service as National FFA Treasurer<ref name="The HMDB" /> *'''1950''' Death<ref name="The HMDB" />
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Agricultural education]] [[Category:1892 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]]
